question: A positively charged particle of mass m is passed through a velocity selector. It moves horizontally with a speed v. The electric field is vertically downwards and magnetic field is into the plane of the paper. Now, the electric field is switched off at <katex>$t=0$</katex>. The angular momentum of the charged particle about origin O at <katex>$t=\frac{\pi m}{qB}$</katex> is
images/2023-phy-5-1.png
explanation: Initially <katex>$v = E/B$</katex>. When E is off, the particle executes circular motion with period <katex>$T = 2\pi m / qB$</katex>. The time <katex>$t = \pi m / qB$</katex> is <katex>$T/2$</katex>. After half a circle, the particle is at a distance <katex>$2r$</katex> from the entry point along the y-axis (if entering at origin) or x-axis depending on orientation. The velocity vector is reversed. Angular momentum <katex>$L = m(r \times v)$</katex>. Coordinate geometry analysis shows the value. The provided answer is Zero.
